[[Sheffield Hallam University]] }} '''Eric Roger Patrick Miller'''[http://indigo.ie/~kands/kands/html/miller.html Tom Keogh [[Sunday World]]] (born September 23, 1975, [[Dublin]], [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]]) is a former Irish [[rugby union]] and [[Gaelic football]] player. As a rugby player Miller played for, among others [[Old Wesley]], [[Leicester Tigers]],[Ulster],[[Leinster Rugby|Leinster]], the [[Barbarian F.C.|Barbarians]], [[Ireland national rugby union team|Ireland]] and the [[British and Irish Lions]]. After retiring as a rugby player, Miller switched football codes and went onto play gaelic football for [[Dublin GAA|Dublin]]. ==Early years== As a schoolboy and youth, Miller played several sports. He was educated at [[Wesley College, Dublin]] where he played both [[rugby union]] and [[cricket]]. At the same time he played [[football (soccer)|soccer]] for [[Leicester Celtic]], a team whose former players also included [[Damian Duff]]. He also played [[gaelic football]] for [[Ballyboden St. Enda's]] and, together with [[Brian Stynes]], he helped them win a [[Dublin Under 21 Football Championship|Dublin under 21 Championship]] title in 1995. Miller eventually opted to concentrate on rugby union and spent the 1995-96 season playing for [[Old Wesley]]. He also represented [[Leinster Rugby|Leinster]] for the first time at senior level. .[http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/rugby/rugby-union/miller-seeks-to-cement-place-in-irelands-heart-624124.html Interview at www.independent.co.uk][http://www.leicesterceltic.ie/explayers.html Leicester Celtic Ex Players][http://www.ercrugby.com/eng/36_4571.php?player=437&includeref=dynamic www.ercrugby.com][http://www.independent.ie/sport/miller-ready-for-terenure-debut-430293.html www.independent.ie] ==Leicester Tigers== In 1996 Miller joined [[Leicester Tigers]] and went onto make 12 appearances for them in the [[Heineken Cup]]. His impressive performances for the Tigers saw him make his debut for [[Ireland national rugby union team|Ireland]] and then represent the [[British and Irish Lions]]. While playing for the Tigers, he also attended both [[Loughborough University]], where he studied for a degree in [[Physical Education]], and [[Sheffield Hallam University]] . ==Leinster== Miller first played for [[Leinster Rugby|Leinster]] during the 1995-96 season while still attached to [[Old Wesley]]. After his spell with [[Leicester Tigers]] he returned to Ireland and initially linked up with [[Terenure College RFC]] and [[Ulster Rugby|Ulster]]. In 2000 he returned to Leinster and went onto make 148 appearances for the province in the [[Celtic League (rugby union)|Celtic League]] and the [[Heineken Cup]]. Back at Leinster he helped them win the 2001-02 Celtic League title. ==Rugby international== ===Ireland=== As well as winning senior caps, Miller also represented Ireland at [[Ireland national schoolboy rugby union team|schoolboy]], U21 and [[Ireland A national rugby union team|A]] levels. In 1996 he was a prominent member of the Ireland U21 team that won a [[Triple Crown (rugby union)|Triple Crown]] for the first time. Between 1997 and [[2005 Ireland rugby union tour of Japan|2005]], Miller made 48 appearances and scored 30 points, including 6 tries, for [[Ireland national rugby union team|Ireland]]. He made his international debut in a friendly against [[Italy national rugby union team|Italy]] on January 4, 1997. He went onto play for Ireland at both the [[1999 Rugby World Cup squads|1999]] and [[2003 Rugby World Cup squads|2003]] World Cups. He scored two of six his tries in one game against [[Namibia national rugby union team|Namibia]] during the [[2003 Rugby World Cup]]. He made his final appearance for Ireland in a friendly against [[Japan national rugby union team|Japan]] on June 19, 2005.[http://www.magnersleague.com/570_1125.php www.magnersleague.com][http://www.irishrugby.ie/227_7678.php?player=3800&includeref=dynamic Ireland stats] ===British and Irish Lions=== After playing just four senior internationals for [[Ireland national rugby union team|Ireland]], Miller was selected by the [[British and Irish Lions]] for their [[1997 British Lions tour to South Africa|1997 tour of South Africa]]. He played in five games during the tour, lining up against the [[Border Bulldogs]], [[Blue Bulls|Northern Transvaal]], [[Natal Sharks|Natal]] and the [[Free State Cheetahs]]. A bout of flu saw him miss the first test against [[South Africa national rugby union team|South Africa]] but he recovered in time to feature in the second test on June 28, 1997. However injury saw him miss the third test.[http://www.lionsrugby.com/6012.php?player=437&includeref=dynamic www.lionsrugby.com] At 21 he was youngest member of the touring party. ===Barbarians=== Miller has also played for the [[Barbarian F.C.|Barbarians]] several times. In May 2004 he was included in their squad for games against [[England national rugby union team|England]], [[Wales national rugby union team|Wales]] and [[Scotland national rugby union team|Scotland]].[http://www.rte.ie/sport/2004/0519/barbarians.html www.rte.ie] On May 25, 2005 he featured in a 38-7 defeat against [[Scotland national rugby union team|Scotland]] at [[Pittodrie Stadium|Pittodrie]].[http://www.irishrugby.ie/6855_4622.php www.irishrugby.ie] ==Return to Gaelic football== After retiring as a rugby player in January 2006, Miller started playing [[gaelic football]] again. In August 2006 he came on as a substitute for [[Ballyboden St. Enda's]] in a [[Dublin AFL Division 1]] game against [[Thomas Davis (GAA Club)|Thomas Davis]].[http://www.irishrugby.ie/6855_6108.php www.irishrugby.ie] On December 5, 2006 he played his first senior game for [[Dublin GAA|Dublin]] against [[Louth GAA|Louth]].[http://www.hoganstand.com/Dublin/ArticleForm.aspx?ID=69898 www.hoganstand.com] He has since ended his short return to GAA. ==Retirement== Since finishing with Gaelic Football, Miller set up his own personal training company called the real golf solution.[http://www.ericmillergolfsolution.com/theteam.html] He has also had a rather successful coaching career. In September 2006 he undertook a coaching position in [[Wesley College, Dublin]] until 2009.
